column9: writing something, especially a letter, speech, or piece of music.
column10: ...composing an answer that only one person would read.
column11: He spent his free time composing music.
column12: She is composing a letter of complaint to the company.

column9: to mention a subject briefly.
column10: Over the years I've touched on this plenty of times.
column11: The report touched on the issue of climate change.
column12: In his speech, he touched on the need for educational reform.

column9: giving all or a large part of one's time or resources to a particular person, activity, or cause.
column10: I've never done a single episode just devoted to the topic.
column11: She is devoted to her children.
column12: He devoted his life to helping the poor.

column9: the process of being mentally stimulated to do or feel something, especially something creative.
column10: Hopefully I can give you some inspiration.
column11: His trip to India was the inspiration for his new novel.
column12: She is a true inspiration to us all.

column9: to manage with just enough money or resources to survive.
column10: ...you need English in order to get by on a daily basis.
column11: We don't have much money, but we get by.
column12: I can get by in French, but I'm not fluent.

column9: experiences that have a strong influence on a person's character and development.
column10: ...persuade your parents to take you to the UK where you can have various formative experiences in English.
column11: His time in the army was a formative experience.
column12: The ones who are indistinguishable from native speakers are ones who had formative experiences in childhood.

column9: skilled and experienced.
column10: You can be totally proficient, and even better at speaking than many natives.
column11: She is proficient in several languages.
column12: He is a proficient computer programmer.

column9: able to express thoughts and feelings easily and clearly.
column10: ...meaning more articulate, more persuasive...
column11: She is a highly articulate and intelligent speaker.
column12: He was unable to give an articulate account of what had happened.

column9: good at persuading someone to do or believe something.
column10: ...meaning more articulate, more persuasive...
column11: He can be very persuasive.
column12: It was a persuasive argument.

column9: to keep or continue to have something.
column10: You will probably always retain certain traces of your accent.
column11: She has lost her battle to retain control of the company.
column12: The house retains much of its original charm.

column9: small signs or amounts of something.
column10: You will probably always retain certain traces of your accent.
column11: Police found traces of blood in the car.
column12: There was no trace of fear in his voice.

column9: an influence or effect that is lasting.
column10: ...and some imprints of the grammar or vocabulary of your first language.
column11: The war has left a lasting imprint on the country.
column12: His style of management has left its imprint on the company.

column9: in a way that is based on facts and what is possible.
column10: Realistically this ability seems to go away after about your 18th birthday.
column11: Realistically, we can't afford to buy a new car.
column12: We need to think realistically about our chances of success.

column9: so similar that you cannot see any difference between them.
column10: The ones who are pretty much indistinguishable from native speakers...
column11: The fake painting was almost indistinguishable from the original.
column12: Her accent is indistinguishable from that of a native speaker.

column9: important or noticeable.
column10: ...when English is a significant part of your life.
column11: There has been a significant increase in the number of students.
column12: It is significant that he did not mention the subject.

column9: speech that is natural and not planned or rehearsed.
column10: Spontaneous speech - being able to talk off the top of your head.
column11: The interview was a good example of his spontaneous speech.
column12: Practicing with native speakers can help improve your spontaneous speech.

column2: off the top of your head
column9: from the knowledge you have in your memory, without checking.
column10: ...being able to talk off the top of your head.
column11: I can't tell you the answer off the top of my head.
column12: What's the capital of Mongolia? I don't know off the top of my head.

column9: the act of pausing before doing or saying something.
column10: ...without too much hesitation.
column11: After a moment's hesitation, she agreed to his proposal.
column12: He answered without hesitation.

column9: the range of language styles from very formal to very informal.
column10: ...native speakers know language from across the formality spectrum.
column11: Understanding the formality spectrum is key to communicating appropriately.
column12: Her writing shows a good command of the formality spectrum.

column9: communication without the use of words, such as through body language, gestures, and facial expressions.
column10: Non-verbal communication skills (social and psychological factors).
column11: Body language is a powerful form of non-verbal communication.
column12: She is an expert in non-verbal communication.

column9: in a way that is suitable or right for a particular situation.
column10: ...to respond properly and appropriately.
column11: She was dressed appropriately for the occasion.
column12: He didn't think she had behaved appropriately.

column9: to include something as part of something larger.
column10: ...making quite big changes to your everyday life in order to incorporate new habits.
column11: We have incorporated all the latest safety features into the design.
column12: The new car design incorporates a number of improvements.

column9: a summary or list of the main points of something.
column10: Here's a run-down of the things you can and should do.
column11: Can you give me a quick run-down of the meeting?
column12: I'll give you a run-down of the day's events.

column9: to include a large number of people or things in a search or activity.
column10: Spread your net quite wide and try to hear lots of different things.
column11: When looking for a job, it's a good idea to spread your net wide.
column12: The police are spreading their net wide in the search for the missing child.

column9: to take part in a particular activity.
column10: You must regularly engage in meaningful conversation.
column11: She has engaged in a number of charitable activities.
column12: The two countries have agreed to engage in talks.

column9: logical and well-organized; easy to understand.
column10: ...the most important thing is that you're having a coherent and fluent conversation.
column11: She gave a coherent account of the incident.
column12: He was too drunk to be coherent.

column9: to become completely involved in an activity.
column10: Immerse yourself in the English language.
column11: She immersed herself in her work to forget her problems.
column12: He immersed himself in the culture of the country.

column9: a continuous description of an event as it is happening.
column10: Have a running commentary going at all times.
column11: The book is a running commentary on the author's life.
column12: He gave a running commentary on the football match.

column9: goals that can be quantified and tracked for progress.
column10: Set small measurable goals.
column11: Setting measurable goals is important for motivation.
column12: One of my measurable goals is to run 5km in under 25 minutes.

column9: the hard work and effort that someone puts into an activity or purpose because they think it is important.
column10: With some organisation, dedication, positivity and time you can make it!
column11: He has shown great dedication to his work.
column12: It takes a lot of dedication to become a doctor.
